description: Built during the early 1800's, 6 David Mews consists of three interlocking historic industrial buildings. These have been stripped back, retro-fitted and co-joined and currently function as an office and exhibition space for AVR London.

factsheet.heading: The Building
paragraphs: Built during the early 1800's, 6 David Mews consists of three interlocking historic industrial buildings. These have been stripped back, retro-fitted and co-joined and currently function as an office and exhibition space for AVR London.

Working with Light Earth Design there is a scheme emerging to introduce further light into the heart of the ground floor, re-purposing the roof with internal landscaped terraces to create a mindful workplace in the heart of Greenwich.

factsheet.heading: AVR London
paragraphs: Established in 2006 by Joseph Robson, AVR London is a collective of artists, architects and researchers. Their wide range of knowledge allows for more divergent thinking, creating a more fluid process with proven results. With over 100 years combined experience, AVR London have created thousands of images for architects and developers. Whether it is a beautifully crafted illustrative CGI or a verified planning view the approach carries the same beliefs in collaboration, adaptability and proven and refined methodologies.
The new studio in Greenwich offers more opportunity to share knowledge with emerging artists and engage with and guide future 3D artists through annual placements and mentorship
The studio prides itself in continuous professional development, providing opportunities for artists to expand their skills through research, discussion and idea-sharing.

factsheet.heading: The Artwork
paragraphs: This Much I'm Worth (The Self-Evaluating Artwork) by Rachel Ara

This much I’m worth [The self-evaluating artwork] is a digital art piece that continually displays its sale value through a series of complex algorithms called ‘the endorsers’. It is constructed with materials that have a history loaded with association. It is both a functional object and spectacle
seeking to question values, worth and algorithmic bias.

This work is the first in an edition of the ‘This Much I’m Worth’ series, shown at Anise Gallery in 2017, it went on to be exhibited at the Whitechapel Gallery, London and then at the Vienna Bienniale in 2019.
